question.title: Will Congo receive mpox vaccines from Canada by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Congo is confirmed to have received mpox vaccines from Canada. If no such confirmation is made by the resolution date, or if Congo receives mpox vaccines from a source other than Canada, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will Switzerland's SMI index reach or exceed 12,500 points by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, at any point between October 1, 2023 and August 31, 2024, Switzerland's SMI index reaches or exceeds 12,500 points. The 12,500 point level is chosen as a representative value that the index might have been at before a significant drop. Verification will be based on official index reports from reputable financial market data providers such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or the SIX Swiss Exchange. If the index does not reach 12,500 points during this period, the question resolves as NO. Note that intraday highs count for resolution; the index does not need to close at or above 12,500 points.

question.title: Will Russia's Federation Council pass a major economic reform bill opposed by President Putin by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Russia's Federation Council passes a major economic reform bill that is explicitly opposed by President Vladimir Putin or his administration. To qualify:

1. The bill must be related to economic policy, such as fiscal spending, taxation, or monetary policy.
2. It must be passed by the Federation Council, regardless of whether it becomes law.
3. The opposition from President Putin or his administration must be clearly reported by at least two major international news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, Financial Times).
4. The bill must be described as 'major' or 'significant' by these news sources in terms of its potential impact on the Russian economy.

If no such bill is passed by the Federation Council by August 31, 2024, or if a bill is passed but does not meet all the above criteria, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will the WHO declare the COVID-19 outbreak in the Middle East no longer a global emergency by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, the World Health Organization (WHO) officially declares that the COVID-19 outbreak in the Middle East is no longer considered a global emergency. For a YES resolution:

1. The WHO must make a public announcement explicitly stating that the COVID-19 outbreak in the Middle East is no longer a global emergency.
2. This declaration must be reported by at least two major international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN).
3. The declaration must specifically refer to the Middle Eastern COVID-19 outbreak, not a global COVID-19 situation in general.

The question will resolve as NO if:
1. The WHO does not make such a declaration by August 31, 2024.
2. The WHO makes a declaration about COVID-19 that does not specifically address the Middle Eastern outbreak.
3. The WHO maintains or escalates the emergency status of the Middle Eastern COVID-19 outbreak.

Note: If the WHO has already declared the Middle Eastern COVID-19 outbreak no longer a global emergency prior to this question's start date, the question will still resolve based on the status as of August 31, 2024.

1. The relocation must be officially announced by the company or its leadership.
2. The announcement must be reported by at least two major, reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, Wall Street Journal, New York Times).

This statement must be covered by at least two prominent international news agencies (like Reuters, AP, BBC, or Al Jazeera) or by the World Health Organization (WHO). The announcement should clearly indicate that the cholera epidemic that started in 2023 has been controlled or terminated. If no such formal announcement is made and reported by the given date, or if the epidemic is still in progress, the inquiry will be deemed negative.

question.title: Will Canada add at least 200,000 jobs in any single month between October 2023 and July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, in any month from October 2023 through July 2024, Canada records a monthly increase of at least 200,000 jobs in an official jobs report. The data must be confirmed by Statistics Canada in their monthly Labour Force Survey. If no such monthly increase is reported within this period, the question resolves as NO. Revisions to previously reported data will not be considered for resolution; only the initial reported figures for each month will be used.

question.title: Will New Jersey hold a referendum on police reform by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the state of New Jersey officially conducts a referendum regarding police reform. The referendum must be a formal, state-wide vote on a proposed constitutional amendment or legislative measure specifically addressing police reform. The occurrence of the referendum must be verifiable through official state government announcements or reports from at least three major, reputable news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, or CNN). If no such referendum is held by the specified date, or if a planned referendum is cancelled or postponed beyond July 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO. Note that this question only concerns the occurrence of the referendum itself, not its outcome.

question.title: Will the Georgia Senate pass a total abortion ban by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Georgia Senate successfully passes legislation enacting a total abortion ban. For the purpose of this question, a 'total abortion ban' refers to legislation that prohibits all or nearly all abortions, with possible exceptions only for cases involving rape, incest, or threat to the mother's life. The passage of such legislation must be confirmed through official Georgia legislative records. If no such legislation is passed by the specified date, or if only partial restrictions are enacted, the question will resolve as NO. Note that this question only concerns the passage of the bill in the Senate, not its final enactment into law.

If the tariff is reduced below 100% or completely removed at any point up to and including August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO. Temporary suspensions or waivers of the tariff that are explicitly stated to be temporary and do not permanently alter the 100% rate will not affect the resolution of this question.

The announcement must come from an official government source, such as the Prime Minister's office or the Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources, and be reported by at least two major international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or Bloomberg). The announcement must clearly indicate an intention to construct additional reactors beyond the two already planned, not just expansions or modifications to the existing plans. If no such announcement is made by the resolution date, or if the announcement only reaffirms or provides updates on the existing two-reactor plan, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will the Swiss National Bank announce an interest rate cut by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Swiss National Bank officially announces a decrease in its policy rate by July 31, 2024. The announcement must be confirmed through official statements from the Swiss National Bank or reported by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Governing Board and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual SNB members will not count for resolution. If no such official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will Boar's Head issue a recall of deli meats due to a listeria outbreak by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Boar's Head officially announces a recall of any of its deli meat products due to a listeria outbreak. The recall must be confirmed through at least one of the following sources:

1. An official announcement on Boar's Head's website or social media channels
2. A press release from Boar's Head
3. An announcement from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) specifically mentioning a Boar's Head recall
4. Reports from at least three major news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, CNN, New York Times) citing official sources

The recall must explicitly mention listeria as the reason for the product withdrawal. If no such recall meeting these criteria is announced by the specified date, the question will resolve as NO.

This recall was announced on July 26, 2024.

    2. **CDC and FDA Involvement**: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) were involved in the investigation of the listeria outbreak linked to meats sliced at deli counters, including Boar's Head products.

    3. **News Reports**: Major news outlets have reported on the recall, citing official sources. For example, USA Today and The New York Times have covered the story, mentioning the recall of Boar's Head deli meats due to listeria contamination.

    Given these sources, it is clear that Boar's Head issued a recall of its deli meat products due to a listeria outbreak before August 2024.

This inquiry will be answered with YES if, by August 31, 2024, Boar's Head makes an official statement regarding the withdrawal of any of its deli meat items due to a listeria outbreak. The recall must be verified through at least one of the following channels:

1. A formal announcement on Boar's Head's official website or social media platforms
2. A press statement issued by Boar's Head
3. A communication from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) that specifically references a Boar's Head recall
4. Coverage from at least three major news organizations (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, CNN, New York Times) referencing official sources

The recall must clearly state listeria as the cause for the product withdrawal. If no such recall is announced by the specified deadline, the question will be answered as NO.

question.title: Will the headquarters of a major energy company be fully relocated to Austin, Texas by July 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, a major energy company has fully relocated its headquarters from its original location to Austin, Texas. For the resolution to be affirmative:

1. The relocation must be officially announced by the company or its leadership.
2. The announcement must be reported by at least two major, reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, Wall Street Journal, New York Times).
3. The new headquarters must be operational in Austin, Texas, with key executive functions transferred.

Partial relocations or plans still in progress by July 31, 2024, will not be sufficient for a YES resolution. If the move is not completed and operational by this date, or if the company decides against the move, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy publicly condemn a Russian aerial attack on Kyiv by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is reported to have publicly condemned a Russian aerial attack on Kyiv. The condemnation must meet the following criteria:

1. It must be made by Volodymyr Zelenskyy in his capacity as the President of Ukraine.
2. It must specifically refer to an aerial attack or military action by Russia against Kyiv.
3. The condemnation must be publicly accessible, such as through official government statements, press conferences, or social media posts from verified accounts.
4. The condemnation must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, Al Jazeera).

The question will resolve as NO if:
1. No such condemnation meeting the above criteria is reported by August 31, 2024.
2. Zelenskyy is no longer the President of Ukraine by the resolution date.
3. The reported condemnation is later proven to be false or misattributed.

Note: This question does not require the attack to be new or future; it could be a condemnation of any Russian aerial attack on Kyiv, including ongoing conflicts or past events, as long as the condemnation itself occurs within the specified timeframe.

The announcement must come from an official source within Dubai's local government and be reported by at least two reputable international news organizations. The restrictions or regulations should be specifically targeted at reducing the number of short-term rental units available to tourists or altering the way they operate. Mere discussions or proposals without a formal announcement will not be sufficient for a YES resolution. If no such official announcement is made by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

perplexity_verification.chain_of_thought:
To resolve this question, we need to find information about the World Health Organization's (WHO) declarations or announcements regarding the current polio outbreak up to August 31, 2024.
    
    1. **WHO's Recent Statements**: The latest available information from WHO does not indicate that the polio outbreak has been declared over. In fact, recent reports highlight ongoing efforts to combat polio outbreaks in various regions, including the detection of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) in Gaza and other parts of the world.
    
    2. **Global Polio Eradication Efforts**: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) continues to work on interrupting all remaining transmission of endemic wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) and stopping all outbreaks of variant poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2). However, there is no indication that the current outbreak has been declared over.
    
    3. **Emergency Committee Meetings**: The WHO's Emergency Committee under the International Health Regulations (2005) has met to discuss the polio situation, but there is no record of the outbreak being declared over. Instead, the committee has emphasized the need for continued vigilance and action to combat polio.
    
    Given these points, there is no evidence to suggest that the WHO has declared the current polio outbreak over by August 31, 2024. Therefore, the question can be resolved with a definitive answer.

question.title: Will Arizona hold a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Arizona officially conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. For a positive resolution:

1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the Arizona state government.
2. The referendum must explicitly address the issue of abortion rights protection.
3. The results of the referendum must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

The question will resolve as NO if:

1. No such referendum occurs by August 31, 2024.
2. A planned referendum is cancelled or postponed beyond the specified date.
3. A referendum is held, but it does not specifically focus on enshrining protection for abortion rights.

Note: This question does not consider the outcome of the referendum, only whether it takes place within the specified timeframe.

The recognition must not be based on her age at the time of her appointment to a major orchestra, such as the Berlin Philharmonic. A 'major orchestra' is defined as a professional symphony orchestra with international recognition and a regular concert season. The recognition must not explicitly state that she is the youngest person to hold such a position. If such recognition does not occur by the specified date, or if another conductor is recognized as younger in such a role, the question resolves as YES.

para_P.title: Will Karina Canellakis be acknowledged as the youngest music director of a prominent orchestra by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be deemed affirmative if, by July 31, 2024, Karina Canellakis is formally acknowledged and publicized by a minimum of two esteemed music industry publications or organizations as the youngest music director of a prominent orchestra. The acknowledgment must be based on her age at the moment of her appointment to a major orchestra, such as the Berlin Philharmonic. A 'prominent orchestra' is characterized as a professional symphony orchestra with global recognition and a regular concert season. The acknowledgment must clearly state that she is the youngest individual to occupy such a position. If no such acknowledgment occurs by the specified date, or if another conductor is recognized as younger in such a role, the inquiry will be resolved as negative.

question.title: Will the U.S. government initiate a new legal challenge against a private space launch by July 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the U.S. government initiates a new legal challenge against a private space launch. For a positive resolution, the following criteria must be met:

1. The legal challenge must be officially filed in a U.S. court.
2. The challenge must be specifically against a private space launch.
3. The legal action must be reported by at least two major, reputable news outlets.

The question will resolve as NO if no such legal challenge meeting all the above criteria is initiated by the U.S. government by July 31, 2024.

Note: This question does not consider any past or current legal challenges, only new ones initiated after October 1, 2023.

perplexity_verification.chain_of_thought:
To resolve this question, we need to understand the current status of Pier 1 Imports' bankruptcy proceedings and whether it has officially emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy by July 31, 2024.

    1. **Pier 1 Imports' Bankruptcy History**: Pier 1 Imports filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in February 2020. It initially aimed to reorganize about 450 locations but ultimately decided to liquidate all stores due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

    2. **Acquisition by Retail Ecommerce Ventures (REV)**: In June 2020, REV acquired Pier 1 Imports for $31 million and planned to revive the brand as an e-commerce store. This indicates a shift from physical retail to online operations.

    3. **Current Status**: The latest information available indicates that Pier 1 Imports did not emerge from bankruptcy in the traditional sense of reorganizing its brick-and-mortar stores. Instead, its brand and intellectual property were acquired by REV, which later transferred to Omni Retail Enterprises.

    4. **Omni Retail Enterprises' Acquisition**: Omni acquired the REV portfolio, including Pier 1 Imports, and is now the parent company. This change does not imply Pier 1 Imports emerging from bankruptcy as a standalone entity but rather a transfer of its assets to a new owner.

    Given these points, Pier 1 Imports as a retail chain did not emerge from bankruptcy by reorganizing its financial position and continuing operations in the traditional sense. The brand continues as an e-commerce entity under new ownership, which does not meet the criteria for emerging from bankruptcy as specified in the question.

The emergence should not involve a court-approved reorganization plan that allows Pier 1 Imports to continue operations with a restructured financial position. This inquiry will be answered with a YES if Lisa, who is part of the K-pop ensemble Blackpink, executes a solo performance at the Summer Sonic Festival taking place in Tokyo on or before July 31, 2024. For a positive outcome, the following conditions must be satisfied:

1. The performance needs to be officially announced by the organizers of the Summer Sonic Festival.
2. Lisa must perform solo, not as a member of Blackpink or any other collective.
3. The event has to occur in Tokyo.
4. At least two credible news outlets must report on the performance.

If any of these conditions are not fulfilled, or if such a performance does not happen by July 31, 2024, the inquiry will be answered with a NO.

question.title: Will Egypt close its investigation into Novartis's cancer drug pricing by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Egyptian authorities officially announce the closure of their investigation into Novartis regarding the pricing of a cancer drug. The closure must be confirmed by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or local Egyptian news agencies of similar repute). The investigation in question must be specifically related to the pricing of a cancer medication produced by Novartis. If no such closure is announced by the specified date, or if the investigation remains ongoing, the question will resolve as NO. Note that a temporary suspension or pause in the investigation does not count as closure for the purpose of this question.

question.title: Will Nigeria report over 50 cholera-related deaths by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, official reports confirm that the cholera outbreak in Nigeria has resulted in more than 50 deaths. Confirmation must come from at least one of the following sources: Nigerian health authorities, the World Health Organization (WHO), or reputable international news agencies (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or BBC) citing official figures. The death toll must be specifically attributed to the cholera outbreak that began in 2023. If the number of confirmed cholera-related deaths in Nigeria remains at 50 or fewer by the resolution date, or if no reliable data is available, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will Pennsylvania hold a referendum on tax reform by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Pennsylvania officially conducts a public referendum specifically focused on tax reform. The referendum must be a statewide vote, officially organized by the state government, and the results must be publicly reported by credible news sources or official state channels. The referendum topic must directly address tax reform, either proposing new tax policies or modifying existing ones. A general election that includes candidates with differing stances on tax does not qualify; it must be a specific referendum on the issue. If no such referendum occurs by the specified date, or if a planned referendum is cancelled or postponed beyond August 31, 2024, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will the WHO declare the dengue outbreak in Southeast Asia no longer a global emergency by August 2024?

1. The WHO must make a public announcement explicitly stating that the dengue outbreak in Southeast Asia is no longer a global emergency.
2. This declaration must be reported by at least two major international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN).
3. The declaration must specifically refer to the Southeast Asian dengue outbreak, not a global dengue situation in general.

The question will resolve as NO if:
1. The WHO does not make such a declaration by August 31, 2024.
2. The WHO makes a declaration about dengue that does not specifically address the Southeast Asian outbreak.
3. The WHO maintains or escalates the emergency status of the Southeast Asian dengue outbreak.

Note: If the WHO has already declared the Southeast Asian dengue outbreak no longer a global emergency prior to this question's start date, the question will still resolve based on the status as of August 31, 2024.

question.title: Will the headquarters of a major healthcare company be fully relocated to Austin, Texas by July 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, a major healthcare company has fully relocated its headquarters from its original location to Austin, Texas. For the resolution to be affirmative:

1. The relocation must be officially announced by the company or its leadership.
2. The announcement must be reported by at least two major, reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, Wall Street Journal, New York Times).
3. The new headquarters must be operational in Austin, Texas, with key executive functions transferred.

Partial relocations or plans still in progress by July 31, 2024, will not be sufficient for a YES resolution. If the move is not completed and operational by this date, or if the company decides against the move, the question resolves as NO.

1. The WHO must make a public announcement explicitly stating that the mpox outbreak in Africa is no longer a global emergency.
2. This declaration must be reported by at least two major international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN).
3. The declaration must specifically refer to the African mpox outbreak, not a global mpox situation in general.

The question will resolve as NO if:
1. The WHO does not make such a declaration by August 31, 2024.
2. The WHO makes a declaration about mpox that does not specifically address the African outbreak.
3. The WHO maintains or escalates the emergency status of the African mpox outbreak.

Note: If the WHO has already declared the African mpox outbreak no longer a global emergency prior to this question's start date, the question will still resolve based on the status as of August 31, 2024.

question.title: Will the FTC's rule banning noncompete agreements be reinstated by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, the Federal Trade Commission's rule banning noncompete agreements, which was blocked by a federal judge in Texas, is reinstated through legal or administrative means. Reinstatement must be confirmed through official announcements by the FTC, court rulings, or other authoritative legal sources, and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, The Wall Street Journal, or The New York Times). The reinstatement must be effective and not merely proposed or pending. If the rule is not reinstated and in effect by August 31, 2024, the question resolves as NO. Partial reinstatements or modifications to the original rule that still substantially ban noncompete agreements would qualify for a YES resolution.

perplexity_verification.chain_of_thought:
The FTC's rule banning noncompete agreements was initially set to take effect on September 4, 2024. However, it was blocked by a federal judge in Texas, which issued a preliminary injunction against the FTC's non-compete ban for the plaintiffs in the case *Ryan, LLC v. Federal Trade Commission*. The court in *Ryan* also indicated that it would make a final decision on the merits by August 30, 2024, which could potentially include a nationwide injunction.

    On August 20, 2024, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas issued a decision that not only blocked the non-compete rule but also held that the FTC lacks any substantive rulemaking authority with respect to unfair methods of competition. This decision effectively sets aside the non-compete rule, and any appeal would be heard by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit and possibly the U.S. Supreme Court.

    Given this information, as of the current date (September 21, 2024), there has been no reinstatement of the FTC's rule banning noncompete agreements by August 31, 2024. The legal challenges and the court's decision have blocked the rule from taking effect, and there has been no subsequent reinstatement through legal or administrative means that has been confirmed through official announcements by the FTC, court rulings, or other authoritative legal sources and reported by major news outlets.

    Therefore, based on the available information, the question can be resolved as NO, since the rule was not reinstated and in effect by August 31, 2024.

The non-reinstatement must be effective and not merely proposed or pending. If the rule is reinstated and in effect by August 31, 2024, the question resolves as NO. question.title: Will Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy publicly condemn a Russian attack on Ukrainian civilians by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is reported to have publicly condemned a Russian attack on Ukrainian civilians. The condemnation must meet the following criteria:

1. It must be made by Volodymyr Zelenskyy in his capacity as the President of Ukraine.
2. It must specifically refer to an attack or military action by Russia against Ukrainian civilians.
3. The condemnation must be publicly accessible, such as through official government statements, press conferences, or social media posts from verified accounts.
4. The condemnation must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, Al Jazeera).

The question will resolve as NO if:
1. No such condemnation meeting the above criteria is reported by August 31, 2024.
2. Zelenskyy is no longer the President of Ukraine by the resolution date.
3. The reported condemnation is later proven to be false or misattributed.

Note: This question does not require the attack to be new or future; it could be a condemnation of any Russian attack on Ukrainian civilians, including ongoing conflicts or past events, as long as the condemnation itself occurs within the specified timeframe.

The announcement must be confirmed by official statements from either the Italian or Australian government and reported by at least two reputable international news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or major national news agencies of either country). A 'new form of cooperation' refers to a collaborative initiative or agreement that is distinctly different from their existing partnerships as of October 1, 2023. This could include, but is not limited to, joint ventures in emerging technologies, novel trade agreements, or innovative cultural exchange programs. If no such implementation is confirmed by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

2. The spacecraft must land safely with all crew members in good health.
3. The mission's success must be officially confirmed by JAXA or another authoritative space agency.

The question will resolve as NO if:

- A mission is attempted but fails to meet all the above criteria.

question.title: Will Elon Musk conduct a live interview with Sheryl Sandberg on X by August 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if Elon Musk conducts a live interview with Sheryl Sandberg on X (formerly known as Twitter) by August 31, 2024. For a positive resolution, the following criteria must be met:

1. The interview must be conducted live on the X platform.
2. Elon Musk must be the primary interviewer.
3. Sheryl Sandberg must be the interviewee.
4. The event must be officially announced by X or Elon Musk prior to its occurrence.
5. The interview must be publicly accessible on the X platform.
6. At least two major news outlets (such as CNN, Fox News, MSNBC, Reuters, or Associated Press) must report on the event either before or after it takes place.

If all these conditions are met by August 31, 2024, the question resolves as YES. If any of these conditions are not met by this date, or if the interview does not occur, the question resolves as NO.

The referendum must be a statewide vote that is officially arranged by the state government, and the outcomes must be reported publicly by trustworthy news outlets or official state sources. The subject of the referendum must directly pertain to voting rights, whether it involves proposing new laws or modifying current regulations. A general election featuring candidates with varying views on voting rights does not qualify; it must be a distinct referendum on the matter. If no such referendum takes place by the designated date, or if a scheduled referendum is cancelled or delayed past August 31, 2024, the question will be answered as NO.

question.title: Will Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy publicly condemn a Russian attack on Ukraine by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is reported to have publicly condemned a Russian attack on Ukraine. The condemnation must meet the following criteria:

1. It must be made by Volodymyr Zelenskyy in his capacity as the President of Ukraine.
2. It must specifically refer to an attack or military action by Russia against Ukraine.
3. The condemnation must be publicly accessible, such as through official government statements, press conferences, or social media posts from verified accounts.
4. The condemnation must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, Al Jazeera).

The question will resolve as NO if:
1. No such condemnation meeting the above criteria is reported by August 31, 2024.
2. Zelenskyy is no longer the President of Ukraine by the resolution date.
3. The reported condemnation is later proven to be false or misattributed.

Note: This question does not require the attack to be a new or future attack; it could be a condemnation of any Russian attack on Ukraine, including ongoing conflicts or past events, as long as the condemnation itself occurs within the specified timeframe.

To resolve this question, I've checked the available sources for any information on Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy publicly condemning a Russian attack on Ukraine by August 2024.
    
    1. **Source**: This article from The Hindu, dated August 26, 2024, mentions that Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy condemned Russia's overnight and early morning barrage on Ukraine as "vile" and stated that it involved over 100 missiles and about 100 "Shahed" drones. This clearly meets the criteria for public condemnation of a Russian attack by Zelenskyy.
    
    2. **Source**: This CNN article, dated August 27, 2024, also reports on Zelenskyy's statements regarding the Russian missile strikes and his characterization of the attack, further confirming that he publicly condemned the Russian attack.
    
    3. **Source**: Additionally, this Al Jazeera article, dated August 24, 2024, mentions Zelenskyy's video address on Ukraine's Independence Day, where he discussed the conflict and Russia's actions, though it does not directly address a specific condemnation within the timeframe. However, it shows Zelenskyy's ongoing engagement with the issue.
    
    Given these sources, it is clear that Zelenskyy did publicly condemn a Russian attack on Ukraine within the specified timeframe, meeting all the criteria outlined in the question details.

not_P.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is reported to have not publicly condemned a Russian attack on Ukraine. The lack of condemnation must meet the following criteria:

1. It must be made by Volodymyr Zelenskyy in his capacity as the President of Ukraine.
2. It must specifically refer to an attack or military action by Russia against Ukraine.
3. The lack of condemnation must be publicly accessible, such as through official government statements, press conferences, or social media posts from verified accounts.
4. The lack of condemnation must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, Al Jazeera).

The question will resolve as NO if:
1. Such a condemnation meeting the above criteria is reported by August 31, 2024.
2. Zelenskyy is still the President of Ukraine by the resolution date.
3. The reported condemnation is later proven to be false or misattributed.

para_P.title: By August 2024, will President Volodymyr Zelenskyy of Ukraine issue a public denunciation of a Russian assault on Ukraine?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will conclude as YES if, by August 31, 2024, it is reported that President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has publicly denounced a Russian assault on Ukraine. The denunciation must fulfill the following conditions:

1. It must be delivered by Volodymyr Zelenskyy in his role as the President of Ukraine.
2. It must specifically address an assault or military action undertaken by Russia against Ukraine.
3. The denunciation must be publicly available, such as through official government announcements, press conferences, or social media posts from verified accounts.
4. The denunciation must be reported by at least two credible international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, Al Jazeera).

The inquiry will resolve as NO if:
1. No such denunciation meeting the above conditions is reported by August 31, 2024.
2. Zelenskyy is no longer serving as the President of Ukraine by the resolution date.
3. The reported denunciation is later found to be inaccurate or misattributed.

Note: This inquiry does not necessitate the assault to be a new or forthcoming event; it could be a denunciation of any Russian assault on Ukraine, including ongoing conflicts or historical incidents, provided that the denunciation itself occurs within the specified timeframe.

question.title: Will the FDA approve MDMA as a therapy for obsessive-compulsive disorder by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) officially approves MDMA (3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine) for use as a therapy for obsessive-compulsive disorder by August 31, 2024. For a positive resolution, the approval must be confirmed through an official announcement from the FDA and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). The approval must specifically be for the use of MDMA in treating obsessive-compulsive disorder, not for any other condition or use. If no such approval is granted by the resolution date, or if the FDA explicitly rejects or delays the approval beyond August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO.

The question pertains to the FDA approval of MDMA as a therapy for obsessive-compulsive disorder by August 31, 2024.
    
    1. **Current Status of MDMA Approval**: The FDA has recently declined to approve MDMA-assisted therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) due to insufficient evidence and the need for more research.

    2. **Research on MDMA for Other Conditions**: While there are ongoing studies exploring MDMA-assisted therapy for various conditions, including obsessive-compulsive disorder, eating disorders, social anxiety, and alcohol use disorder, these studies are still in progress and have not yet led to FDA approvals.

    3. **Timeline for Approval**: Given the recent rejection of MDMA for PTSD and the ongoing nature of research for other conditions, it is unlikely that MDMA would be approved for obsessive-compulsive disorder by August 31, 2024, without significant new developments or announcements that have not been reported in the available sources.

    4. **Search for Official Announcements**: A thorough search of reputable news sources and official FDA announcements did not yield any information indicating that MDMA has been approved for treating obsessive-compulsive disorder by the specified date.

    Based on these points, it is clear that the FDA has not approved MDMA for obsessive-compulsive disorder by August 31, 2024, and there are no indications that such an approval is imminent within the specified timeframe.

This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Maryland does not conduct an official public referendum specifically focused on investing in digital infrastructure in the state. For a YES resolution, the following criteria must be met:

1. The referendum must not be officially announced and conducted by the state of Maryland.
2. The primary focus of the referendum must not be on digital infrastructure investment.
3. The results of the referendum must not be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

If such a referendum occurs or is completed by August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO. Proposed referendums that have been officially conducted by the resolution date count for a YES resolution.

para_P.title: Will Maryland conduct a public vote regarding investments in digital infrastructure before August 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be deemed as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Maryland carries out an official public vote specifically aimed at investing in digital infrastructure within the state. For a YES determination, the following conditions must be fulfilled:

1. The public vote must be officially announced and executed by the state of Maryland.
2. The main emphasis of the public vote must be on investment in digital infrastructure.
3. The outcomes of the public vote must be reported publicly by official state channels or widely recognized media outlets.

If no such public vote takes place or is finalized by August 31, 2024, the inquiry will be resolved as NO. Proposed public votes that have not been officially conducted by the resolution deadline do not count towards a YES determination.

The ban must remain in place without any changes that would effectively legalize the practice. Confirmation of the ban's status should be available through official government sources or reported by at least two reputable international news organizations. If the ban is reversed or significantly weakened to effectively allow the practice before or during August 2024, the question resolves as NO.

perplexity_verification.chain_of_thought:
To resolve this question, we need to examine the current status of the ban on female genital cutting (FGM) in Gambia and any recent developments.
    
    1. **Initial Ban**: The ban on FGM was initially enacted in 2015 as part of the Women's (Amendment) Act, which criminalized the practice.
    
    2. **Attempt to Repeal**: There was a recent attempt to repeal this ban, which was met with significant opposition from human rights groups and activists. The bill to repeal the ban was rejected by Gambia's parliament on July 15, 2024.
    
    3. **Current Status**: As of July 2024, the ban remains in place. The rejection of the repeal bill by the parliament indicates that the government has not officially reversed the ban on FGM.
    
    4. **Confirmation**: The status of the ban has been confirmed through reputable sources, including Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch, which have welcomed the parliament's decision to uphold the ban.
    
    Given this information, it is clear that as of the resolution date (August 31, 2024), the ban on female genital cutting in Gambia has not been reversed and remains in place.

question.title: Will the Artemis program achieve a crewed lunar landing by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, the Artemis program successfully achieves a crewed lunar landing. For a positive resolution:

1. The mission must involve landing at least one human crew member on the lunar surface.
2. The crew must return safely to Earth with all members in good health.
3. The mission's success must be officially confirmed by NASA or another authoritative space agency.
4. The confirmation must be reported by at least two major, reputable news outlets (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, BBC, CNN, New York Times).

The question will resolve as NO if:
- No such mission occurs by the specified date.
- A mission is attempted but fails to meet all the above criteria.
- The Artemis program is used only for lunar orbit missions without landing.

Note: This question does not consider test flights or simulations. Only actual crewed lunar landings count towards resolution.

original_question.title: Will Boeing's Starliner capsule complete a crewed return mission from the ISS by August 2024?
original_question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Boeing's Starliner capsule successfully completes a crewed return mission from the International Space Station (ISS) to Earth. For a positive resolution:

1. The mission must involve the Starliner capsule transporting at least one human crew member from the ISS back to Earth.
2. The capsule must land safely with all crew members in good health.
3. The mission's success must be officially confirmed by NASA or another authoritative space agency.
4. The confirmation must be reported by at least two major, reputable news outlets (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, BBC, CNN, New York Times).

The question will resolve as NO if:
- No such mission occurs by the specified date.
- A mission is attempted but fails to meet all the above criteria.
- The Starliner capsule is used only for uncrewed missions or launches to the ISS without a return flight.

Note: This question does not consider test flights or simulations. Only actual crewed return missions from the ISS count towards resolution.

question.title: Will Virginia conduct a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?

This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Virginia conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. For a YES resolution, the following criteria must be met:

1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the state of Virginia.
2. The primary focus of the referendum must be on abortion rights protection.
3. The referendum results must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

If no such referendum meeting these criteria occurs by August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO. Note that merely proposing or planning a referendum without actually conducting it by the specified date does not qualify for a YES resolution.

question.title: Will Ted Cruz publicly retract his statement about Biden's stance on border security?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Ted Cruz publicly retracts or significantly alters his statement regarding Joe Biden's position on border security. For the purpose of this question, 'publicly' means through official statements, interviews, social media posts from verified accounts, or during public appearances.

    Given these points, it is clear that the U.S. government did resume consideration of liquefied natural gas conversion projects by July 2024, following the lifting of the pause by a federal court.

not_P.title: Will the U.S. government not resume consideration of liquefied natural gas conversion projects by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the U.S. federal government has not officially resumed the consideration of projects aimed at converting liquefied natural gas (LNG) facilities. The lack of resumption must be confirmed through official government announcements or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or The Wall Street Journal). The lack of resumption should involve the absence of active processing or review of LNG conversion project applications by relevant federal agencies. If such a resumption occurs by the resolution date, or if the pause on consideration is lifted, the question resolves as NO. Note that this question does not require the disapproval of any specific projects, only the lack of resumption of the consideration process.

para_P.title: Will the U.S. federal government start evaluating liquefied natural gas conversion initiatives again by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if, by July 31, 2024, the U.S. federal government has officially restarted the evaluation of initiatives focused on converting liquefied natural gas (LNG) facilities. The restart must be verified through formal government statements or reports from at least two credible news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or The Wall Street Journal). The restart should include the active processing or review of LNG conversion project applications by the appropriate federal agencies. If no such restart takes place by the resolution date, or if the halt on evaluation persists, the inquiry will be answered with a NO. It is important to note that this question does not necessitate the endorsement of any specific initiatives, only the renewal of the evaluation process.

question.title: Will Novo Nordisk allow generic production of its obesity treatment by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, Novo Nordisk officially announces or confirms that it will allow generic production of its obesity treatment, effectively not enforcing its patent. This could be through a formal patent withdrawal, a voluntary license agreement, or any other mechanism that allows for unrestricted generic production. Confirmation must come from official company announcements, statements from relevant regulatory bodies, or reports by at least two reputable international news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). If no such announcement or confirmation is made by the specified date, or if Novo Nordisk continues to enforce its patent rights, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will Novo Nordisk permit the production of generic versions of its obesity medication by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be considered YES if, by July 31, 2024, Novo Nordisk publicly declares or verifies that it will permit the creation of generic versions of its obesity medication, thereby effectively not enforcing its patent rights. This could occur via a formal withdrawal of the patent, a voluntary licensing agreement, or any other method that facilitates unrestricted generic production. Verification must be provided through official announcements from the company, statements from pertinent regulatory authorities, or reports from at least two credible international news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). If no such declaration or verification is made by the designated date, or if Novo Nordisk continues to uphold its patent rights, the inquiry will resolve as NO.
